item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (III)
item.description:
This article, the third in a series about restoring a Beocord 9000’s peak program meters (PPM), focuses on installing and calibrating the rebuilt PPM. The initial step involved switching the original current limiting resistors with values suitable for modern SMD LEDs. These LEDs are more efficient and brighter, requiring significantly larger resistors to match the original brightness. Testing showed that 470 Ohm and 330 Ohm resistors for red and green LEDs, respectively, produced slightly brighter output compared to the original 180 Ohm and 120 Ohm resistors...

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the Incandescent Indicator Light Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description:
During the restoration of a Beocord 9000, two indicator lights presented problems. One had a typical issue with a broken lead, while the other had become dim due to a deteriorating filament. To address this, I opted to use SMD LEDs as replacements, similar to a method I’ve used for Beomaster 8000 units, documented on my blog. This provides lasting stability and safeguards against potential shipping damage. However, the Beocord 9000 has more compact reflector housings compared to the Beomaster 8000, necessitating a redesign of the PCBs for the LEDs...

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (II)
item.description:
The Beocord 9000’s rebuilt Peak Program Meters (PPM) display passed a 24-hour test, confirming its functionality. To reattach the red-green covers, I secured the display to ensure a tight seal, preventing light leakage. Using a soldering iron, I melted the plastic posts of the covers, replicating the original attachment method. During cleaning, the glue holding the light guide dissolved, indicating it was likely polyvinyl ester-based.
